body:
I'm running Kubernetes v1.2.3 using the single-node instructions here: http://kubernetes.io/docs/getting-started-guides/docker/ with Docker v1.10. Everything worked as expected for several hours, but now pods are not being scheduled or removed.

I've attempted to update a deployment several times over the last hour. Here is `kubectl get pods` for that deployment:

```
$ kubectl get pods -l role=nfs-server
NAME                          READY     STATUS              RESTARTS   AGE
nfs-server-1605536338-ff5dp   0/1       Terminating         0          26m
nfs-server-2929273945-87ir0   0/1       Terminating         0          10m
nfs-server-3650062886-7regp   0/1       Terminating         0          24m
nfs-server-377129609-3blnt    0/1       Terminating         0          17m
nfs-server-4135136443-iqh32   0/1       ContainerCreating   0          4m
nfs-server-4135136443-ny1op   0/1       Terminating         0          6m
```

The ContainerCreating pod's last event from `kubectl describe` is:

```
Events:
  FirstSeen     LastSeen        Count   From                    SubobjectPath   Type    Reason           Message
  ---------     --------        -----   ----                    -------------   --------------           -------
  4m            4m              1       {default-scheduler }                    Normal  Scheduled        Successfully assigned nfs-server-4135136443-l3fr4 to 127.0.0.1
```

When I delete a pod, the scheduler does seem to start the new pod almost immediately, and the kubelet logs:

```
I0502 23:13:28.627867    1701 kubelet.go:2388] SyncLoop (ADD, "api"): "nfs-server-4135136443-woha5_default(7ac455d2-10bb-11e6-b93b-06b60bd2d431)"  
```

The kubelet then begins logging a readiness check failure every 10s:

```
I0502 23:14:27.160982    1701 prober.go:104] Readiness probe for "nfs-server-1605536338-ff5dp_default(8f573313-10b7-11e6-b93b-06b60bd2d431):nfs-server" failed (failure): dial tcp 172.19.0.2:111: i/o timeout
```

but I can't see any evidence that it actually tries to run the container. Docker doesn't emit any logs. The Docker daemon is responsive, and the image is definitely present. When I run the image using `docker run` it works fine.

Anything I can check?

Thanks!

labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as a support question.
labels.name: kind/support

labels.description: Categorizes an issue or PR as relevant to SIG Cluster Lifecycle.
labels.name: sig/cluster-lifecycle

title: Pod scheduling grinds to a halt on v1.2.3
